author: John Anderson
title: ‘The Gilded Age’ Review: A Rich History Repeats Itself
text:
There’s a sufficient amount of Edith Wharton-esque soap opera in “The Gilded Age” to satisfy anyone’s ache for 120-year-old gossip: How will the nouveau riche Alva Smith Vanderbilt inveigle her way into Mrs. Astor’s old-monied New York society? Will her daughter’s marriage to the Duke of Marlborough make them the Kardashians of their gas-lit era? And who will be invited, during the frigid winter of 1897, to the epic ball at the Waldorf Hotel, the cost of which could have fed 1,000 working-class families for a year?
...
